title: 104_s1092
content:
The "Free Burma Act of 1995" may be cited as the short title. Sanctions against Burma are outlined in the Act. Sanctions against Burma under the "Free Burma Act of 1995" include prohibiting US investments, assistance, trade privileges, importation of goods, and trade and investment treaties. The United States should continue to suspend obligations under bilateral trade and investment treaties with Burma, prohibit the use of US passports for travel to Burma except for diplomatic personnel, limit diplomatic representation from Burma, and suspend foreign assistance to any government selling arms to Burma. The United States will withhold funding from international organizations supporting activities in Burma, instruct financial institutions to vote against loans to Burma, and urge the United Nations to establish a group to monitor Burma's compliance with resolutions. The United States will urge the United Nations to establish an international arms embargo on Burma. SEC. 3. AGREEMENTS TO IMPOSE SANCTIONS ON BURMA. The President must initiate negotiations with all trading partners to support US sanctions against Burma and cease trade and investment in Burma within 15 days of the enactment of the Act. Within 90 days, the President must certify to Congress countries that have failed to enter into agreements or are not enforcing them. The President must withdraw benefits from countries that fail to comply with trade agreements within 90 days. The President must withdraw benefits from countries that fail to comply with trade agreements within 90 days, including special tariff treatment programs and most-favored-nation trade treatment. These provisions apply to goods entered or withdrawn from warehouse for consumption from countries where such actions have been taken. During the designated period, goods from countries complying with trade agreements will have duty rates specified in the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States. SEC. 4. CERTIFICATION.

The President can lift sanctions if Burma meets conditions like releasing political prisoners, implementing election results, and counternarcotics efforts. SEC. 5. SANCTIONS AGAINST THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA.

The Secretary of the Treasury will direct the US executive directors of multilateral financial institutions to vote against any loans to China until they stop arms sales to Burma.

SEC. 6. SANCTIONS AGAINST THE GOVERNMENT OF THAILAND.

All US assistance to Thailand will be withheld until they provide support for Burmese exiles and refugees.

SEC. 7. REPORT. The President must submit a report within 45 days on Burma's chemical and biological weapons capability, US assistance for the democracy movement in Burma, treatment of Burmese individuals in Thailand, and arms sales to Burma. The term "investment" in this Act includes various forms of contributions or commitments of funds, commodities, services, patents, processes, or techniques. The term "humanitarian activities" refers to providing food, medicine, medical supplies, or clothing, excluding cash transfers. "Financial institutions" include organizations like the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund. "United States assistance" encompasses aid provided through grants, sales, loans, leases, credits, guarantees, or insurance by any U.S. government agency to foreign countries. In 1961, various programs were established for sales, credits, and guaranties under the Arms Export Control Act, sales and donations of nonfood commodities under the Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act, financing programs for export sales of nonfood commodities by the Commodity Credit Corporation, and financing under the Export-Import Bank Act of 1945.
